IT (2017) is slick and energetic, but relies too heavily on loud jump scares and CGI to deliver its horror. The strong young cast brings real heart to the story, yet the film keeps interrupting its best moments with over-the-top set pieces that feel more chaotic than scary.

Pennywise looks striking, but his constant, exaggerated appearances drain him of mystery—he becomes predictable rather than terrifying. The movie flirts with deeper themes but never slows down long enough to explore them.

Entertaining, yes—but more spectacle than suspense, and far less haunting than it could have been.

"IT" is a horror film directed by Andy Muschietti, based on Stephen King novel. The story follows a group of kids in Derry, a fictional town, where they are battling against the evil clown called "Pennywise." The young actors give outstanding performances full of fear and friendship, while the creepy effects and jump scares keep you on edge. Overall, it's a thrilling adaptation that captures the book's terror—highly recommended for horror lovers.

Classic movie for terror/horror fans, "It" don't disappoints in the jumpscare, thrilling atmosphere and music works. An incredible — if not the best possible adaptation of the Stephen King's "It" book. This movie really sticks with you after watching it.

Pennywise Delivers, But the Hype Inflated Expectations:

Going into IT with sky-high expectations after years of hype, I found myself satisfied but not blown away - a solid 7/10 experience.

What works brilliantly is the Amblin-esque nostalgia of misfits on bikes battling evil (yes, it predates Stranger Things, and you can feel its influence). The opening twenty minutes establish genuine dread, and the final act delivers thrilling payoff with the Losers' Club sewer confrontation. Skarsgård's Pennywise is genuinely creepy, and the young cast (especially Lillis and Grazer) bring authentic chemistry.

However, the middle sags with repetitive scare sequences following a predictable formula: character alone, creepy buildup, fake-out, real jumpscare, repeat. It's well-crafted but becomes mechanical. Still, as someone diving in before the new prequel series, this was essential viewing - capturing that sweet spot between horror and coming-of-age that King does best.

Worth watching, even if the legend slightly exceeds the reality.

After the gluttony of failed late 2000’s horror remakes, it seemed the horror remake trend wore relatively thin. But when 2017 rolled around, here comes “It” (which is not a remake but rather a second adaptation of the Stephen King book, there was a 1990 TV miniseries) a beautifully haunting, brilliantly crafted & with a much more faithful story carried by a wonderful cast! I can honestly say, for my first horror film theater experience, I was genuinely scared!

A Predictable Horror Chapter.

It is a middling horror revival that leans on predictable jumps and underdeveloped thrills, failing to capture the novel’s chilling depth. Bill Skarsgård’s Pennywise has moments of menace, but the film dilutes him with rote scares that feel repetitive and unearned. The Losers’ Club—Jaeden Martell, Sophia Lillis, Finn Wolfhard, and friends—has charm, but their arcs are rushed, turning potential coming-of-age poignancy into clichés. Derry’s atmosphere is evocative, but the pacing drags, and the narrative meanders without the tension to sustain its 2017 horror hype. What could have been a profound tale of childhood terror becomes a formulaic slog, recycling tropes without the emotional or atmospheric punch to elevate it beyond standard genre fare.
